title.narrative: Plan Sweden Disaster Risk Management and RRM 2013-2014
Plan Sweden Disaster Risk Management and RRM 2013-2014

description.narrative: Det katastrof förebyggande program för 2013-2014 som presenteras av Plan Sverige består av en mekanism för snabba insatser samt tre landsspecifika projekt (Sudan, Pakistan, Filippinerna). Det två åriga programmet har en total budget på 66,2 MSEK.

The Disaster Risk Management Programme 2013-2014 presented by Plan Sweden consists of a rapid response mechanism along with three country specific projects (Sudan, Pakistan, the Philippines). The two year programme has a total budget of 66.2 MSEK.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Sudan project was selected for results management in Trac. Sida has also conducted a monitoring project visit, as well as recieved an external evaluation.
According to the external evaluation, Plan's Sudan project has a significant role in meeting the needs of the IDPs in Zamzam and Abushok Camps, especially in terms capacity building activities in order to train IDPs to take a leading role in camp management. On a quality level, the project did meet its intended outcome, however, regarding the issue of project quality, some findings are worth noting:
1) The lack of linkage between the project activities and other projects targeting hygiene practice and facilities. Children and other participants expressed concern about lack of water and non-functioning toilets as well as the Child Friendly Spaces not having any effective consideration of gender-related issues, especially regarding latrines which did not meet the minimum standards to ensure the dignity of female children and protection from sexual harassment.The children expressed that the quality of the toilets are more important than the total amount built. The latrines were non-functioning and need regular maintenance which is especially important due to the shortage of vehicles used to dewatering sewage, which could impact the children’s health.
2) It should also be noted that although female community leaders within the camp are being represented, it seems that their participation was not adequately or meaningful, even their feedback and ideas were absent to some extent.
3) Lack of awareness and coordination. When State Council for Child Welfare (SCCW) visits the IDP camps, many of the projects related to child protection were found by accident since there was not enough information about the activities. Poor coordination also had a negative impact on effectiveness on the CP services, including absence of having unified source of information and reporting system and not being linked adequately to CP standards and indicators. The training also needs repetition as many tend to forget what they have learned.
4) Children were not involved in developing the CP policy, strategy, interventions and activities, and no children represented as board members. Children and youth groups who were interviewed in the evaluation process indicated that they were not consulted or involved in the planning phase, despite being the main target group in this project, as well as representing 60% of the IDP residents in the camp. Children with disabilities were also not adequately taken into consideration. 14 children with disabilities in the camps were enrolled, whereas 170 children with disabilities in the camp remained at home.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
